title: Responsive Design Tester - Test Your Website on Any Screen Size
faq_screen_resolution_answer: Screen resolution refers to the total number of pixels that can be displayed on a screen, typically expressed as width √ó height (e.g., 1920√ó1080).
faq_viewport_size_answer: Viewport size is the visible area of a web page within the browser window, measured in CSS pixels.
faq_device_pixel_ratio_answer: Device Pixel Ratio (DPR) is the ratio between physical pixels and CSS pixels, used to support high-resolution (Retina) displays.
faq_web_development: Why is this information important for web development?
faq_web_development_answer: Understanding screen sizes, resolutions, and DPR helps developers create responsive websites that look great on all devices. It's essential for optimizing user experience across different screens.
faq_check_frequency: How often should I check my device information?
faq_check_frequency_answer: It's good practice to check device information when testing responsive designs, debugging display issues, or ensuring your website works correctly across different devices and browsers.
error_message: Unable to detect device information. Please refresh the page and try again.

responsive_tester_title: Responsive Design Tester - Test Your Website on Any Screen Size
responsive_tester_description: A free responsive design tester to check your website's layout on various screen resolutions, including mobile, tablet, and desktop. Perfect for developers and designers.
responsive_tester_intro: Use this powerful tool to test how your website responds to different screen sizes and devices. Select preset device dimensions or enter custom sizes to see how your site adapts to different screens.
simulator_description: Test how your website looks and behaves on different screen sizes and devices. Select preset device dimensions or enter custom sizes.
url_note: Note: Some websites may not display due to security restrictions.
invalid_custom_size_alert: Please enter valid positive numbers for width and height.
website_load_error: Failed to load website. It may be blocked by security policies.
why_responsive_design_text: With the increasing use of mobile devices, responsive design has become essential for modern web development. Google's mobile-first indexing prioritizes mobile-friendly websites in search results, making responsive design crucial for SEO success. Responsive websites automatically adjust their layout to fit different screen sizes, from smartphones to tablets to desktop monitors, providing optimal user experience across all devices. This approach significantly improves conversion rates by ensuring users can easily navigate and interact with your content regardless of their device. As mobile traffic continues to grow and represents over 50% of global web traffic, implementing responsive design is no longer optional‚Äîit's necessary to reach and engage the expanding mobile user base effectively.
testing_tip_1: Test with real content instead of placeholders to ensure layouts handle various content lengths
testing_tip_2: Check that navigation menus are usable on small screens
testing_tip_3: Ensure form elements are usable and easy to fill out on all devices
testing_tip_4: Test touch interactions to ensure tap targets are large enough
testing_tip_5: Check that images and media scale correctly
testing_tip_6: Test loading performance on simulated slow networks (like 3G) to ensure optimal mobile experience
testing_tip_7: Verify font readability by ensuring text size and line height remain legible on the smallest mobile screens
testing_tip_8: Validate interactive elements by confirming buttons and links have adequate spacing to prevent accidental taps on touch devices
iframe_welcome_subtitle: Enter a URL above to start testing your website's responsiveness.
faq_q1: Why can't some websites load in the tester?
faq_a1: Many websites set X-Frame-Options or Content-Security-Policy headers for security reasons, which prevent them from being loaded in iframes. This is a security measure to prevent clickjacking and other attacks. For these websites, you may need to use browser developer tools or other methods for testing.
faq_q2: How does the website in the tester differ from real devices?
faq_a2: This tester primarily simulates different screen sizes but cannot fully replicate all features of real devices, such as touch interactions, device pixel ratios, or specific browser behaviors. For final testing, it's recommended to verify your designs on actual devices.
faq_q3: How can I test specific media query breakpoints?
faq_a3: Use the custom size feature to input your media query breakpoint values. For example, if you have a breakpoint at 768px width, you can input 767px and 768px to test layouts on both sides of the breakpoint.

faq_heading: Frequently Asked Questions About Screen Size Comparison
faq_measure_answer: Screen size is typically measured diagonally from one corner to the opposite corner, expressed in inches or centimeters. For example, a 50" TV means the diagonal measurement is 50 inches.
faq_difference_question: What's the difference between screen size and screen dimensions?
faq_difference_answer: Screen size typically refers to the diagonal measurement, while screen dimensions include the width and height measurements. The actual dimensions depend on the aspect ratio of the screen.
faq_area_question: How do I calculate screen area?
faq_area_answer: Screen area is calculated by multiplying the width by the height. Our comparison tool automatically calculates this for you based on the diagonal size and aspect ratio.
faq_different_question: Why do screens with the same diagonal size look different?
faq_different_answer: Screens with different aspect ratios will have different widths and heights even with the same diagonal measurement. For example, a 27" 16:9 monitor is wider but shorter than a 27" 4:3 monitor.
faq_aspect_question: What is aspect ratio and why does it matter?
faq_aspect_answer: Aspect ratio is the proportional relationship between a screen's width and height (width:height). Common ratios include 16:9 (widescreen), 4:3 (traditional), and 21:9 (ultrawide). It matters because it affects how content is displayed and the overall viewing experience.
viewport_size_explanation: When designing for devices, it's important to understand the difference between viewport sizes and screen resolutions:

compare_page_description: Instantly visualize and compare screen sizes, aspect ratios, and dimensions of any two monitors, laptops, or phones side-by-side. The perfect free tool for developers and designers.

standard_resolutions_page_title: Standard Screen Resolutions List (2025 Updated) | Mobile, Desktop & 4K
standard_resolutions_page_description: Your ultimate, up-to-date cheat sheet for the most common screen resolutions in 2025. Covers all standard sizes for responsive design, from mobile and tablets to desktop and 4K monitors.
standard_resolutions_page_intro: This comprehensive guide provides detailed information about standard screen resolutions, aspect ratios, and recommended image sizes for social media. Essential information for web developers, designers, and content creators.
uhd_4k_usage: Premium TVs, professional monitors, content creation
dci_4k_usage: Cinema projection standard, professional film production
1_1_devices: Instagram square photos, some professional displays
32_9_devices: Super ultrawide curved monitors, dual monitor replacements
360p_platforms: Low bandwidth YouTube, older mobile videos
480p_platforms: Standard definition DVD, older video content
1080p_platforms: Full HD videos, mainstream video platforms
resolution_explanation: Resolution refers to the number of horizontal and vertical pixels on a display. Higher resolution means more detail but requires more processing power and bandwidth.
aspect_ratio_explanation: Aspect ratio is the proportional relationship between width and height, expressed as x:y (e.g., 16:9). It determines the shape of the display area, affecting viewing experience and content layout.
resolution_vs_size_explanation: Resolution is the pixel count, while physical size is the actual dimensions of the screen (usually measured in inches or centimeters). Screens with the same resolution can have different physical sizes, affecting pixel density (PPI/DPI).
design_point1: Design for multiple resolutions and devices, not just one fixed size
design_point2: Utilize responsive design to ensure content displays properly across different screen sizes
design_point3: Prepare 2x or 3x image assets for high-resolution displays like Retina screens
design_point4: Test your designs across various common resolutions
design_point5: Always use the latest recommended sizes when creating images for social media platforms
tech_point1: Use CSS media queries to adjust layouts for different screen sizes
tech_point2: Implement proper viewport meta tags to ensure correct scaling on mobile devices
tech_point3: Use relative units (em, rem, %) rather than fixed pixel sizes
tech_point4: Use CSS srcset and picture elements to load images appropriate for different device pixel ratios
tech_point5: Leverage CSS Grid and Flexbox to create adaptive layouts

ppiCalculator.title: PPI Calculator
ppiCalculator.intro: Calculate the pixel density (pixels per inch) of display devices. Enter screen resolution and diagonal size to get accurate PPI values.
ppiCalculator.pageTitle: PPI Calculator - Easily Calculate Your Screen's Pixel Density | Screen Size Checker
ppiCalculator.pageDescription: Accurately calculate the PPI (Pixels Per Inch) of any screen. Simply enter the resolution and diagonal size to find the pixel density of your monitor, phone, or TV.
ppiCalculator.pageIntro: Calculate the pixel density (pixels per inch) of display devices. Enter screen resolution and diagonal size to get accurate PPI values.
ppiCalculator.horizontalPixelsHelp: Number of pixels across the screen width
ppiCalculator.verticalPixelsHelp: Number of pixels across the screen height
ppiCalculator.diagonalInchesHelp: Diagonal length of the screen in inches
ppiCalculator.ppiDefinition: PPI (Pixels Per Inch) is a unit that measures the pixel density of display devices. It represents how many pixel points are contained within one inch of length. The higher the PPI value, the finer the display effect, and the clearer and sharper images and text appear.
ppiCalculator.ppiFormula: The PPI calculation formula is: PPI = ‚àö(horizontal pixels¬≤ + vertical pixels¬≤) / diagonal inches. First calculate the pixel diagonal length of the screen, then divide by the physical diagonal length to get the number of pixels per inch.
ppiCalculator.ppiImportance: PPI has a direct impact on display quality. High PPI displays can present clearer text, finer image details, and reduce pixel graininess. For designers and developers, understanding the PPI of target devices helps optimize image resources and ensure optimal display effects on screens of different densities.
ppiCalculator.webDesign: Web Design: Prepare appropriate image resources for devices with different PPI
ppiCalculator.appDevelopment: App Development: Ensure UI elements display correctly on various screens
ppiCalculator.printDesign: Print Design: Understand the difference between screen display and print output
ppiCalculator.deviceSelection: Device Selection: Compare display quality of different monitors
ppiCalculator.howToUse: How to Use Our PPI Calculator?
ppiCalculator.step1: Enter the horizontal pixel count of the screen (e.g., 1920)
ppiCalculator.step2: Enter the vertical pixel count of the screen (e.g., 1080)
ppiCalculator.step3: Enter the diagonal size of the screen (e.g., 15.6 inches)
ppiCalculator.step4: The system will automatically calculate and display the PPI value
ppiCalculator.exampleCalculation: For example: A 15.6-inch 1920√ó1080 display has a PPI value of approximately 141.21, meaning each inch contains about 141 pixel points.
ppiCalculator.ppiVsDpi: PPI vs DPI: What's the Difference?
ppiCalculator.ppiVsDpiExplanation: PPI and DPI are often confused, but they have different application scenarios. PPI (Pixels Per Inch) is mainly used to describe the pixel density of digital display devices, while DPI (Dots Per Inch) is mainly used to describe the resolution of printing devices. In the context of web design and screen display, we typically use PPI to measure display quality.
ppiCalculator.lowPPI: Low Density (72-120 PPI): Traditional monitors, large TVs
ppiCalculator.mediumPPI: Medium Density (120-200 PPI): Standard laptops, desktop monitors
ppiCalculator.highPPI: High Density (200-300 PPI): High-resolution laptops, tablets
ppiCalculator.veryHighPPI: Very High Density (300+ PPI): Smartphones, Retina displays

goodPPI.question: What is a good PPI for a monitor?
goodPPI.answer: For general use, 100-150 PPI is adequate. For professional work, 200+ PPI is recommended. Gaming typically works well with 100-200 PPI, while graphic design benefits from 200+ PPI for sharp detail work.

higherBetter.question: Does a higher PPI always mean better image quality?
higherBetter.answer: Not necessarily. While higher PPI provides sharper images, other factors like color accuracy, contrast ratio, and panel technology also significantly impact overall image quality. Very high PPI can also strain system resources.

gamingEditing.question: How does PPI affect gaming and video editing?
gamingEditing.answer: For gaming, moderate PPI (100-200) often provides the best balance of sharpness and performance. For video editing, higher PPI (200+ PPI) helps with precise editing and color grading, but requires more powerful hardware.

humanEye.question: Can the human eye tell the difference between high PPI displays?
humanEye.answer: The human eye can typically distinguish up to about 300 PPI at normal viewing distances. Beyond this point, improvements become less noticeable unless viewing very close to the screen.

referenceTable.title: Typical PPI Values for Common Devices

context.retina: High-resolution 'Retina' display, great for sharp text and images.
context.professional: Very high-resolution display, excellent for professional creative work.

aspectRatioCalculator.title: Aspect Ratio Calculator
aspectRatioCalculator.intro: Calculate new dimensions while maintaining a specific aspect ratio. Enter original dimensions and get proportionally scaled new dimensions.
aspectRatioCalculator.pageTitle: Aspect Ratio Calculator - Calculate Proportional Dimensions | Screen Size Checker
aspectRatioCalculator.pageDescription: Free aspect ratio calculator to maintain proportions when resizing images, videos, or layouts. Calculate new dimensions while preserving the original aspect ratio.
aspectRatioCalculator.pageIntro: Calculate new dimensions while maintaining a specific aspect ratio. Enter original dimensions and get proportionally scaled new dimensions.
aspectRatioCalculator.width2Help: Enter new width, height will be calculated automatically
aspectRatioCalculator.height2Help: Enter new height, width will be calculated automatically
aspectRatioCalculator.aspectRatioDefinition: Aspect ratio is the proportional relationship between the width and height of an image, screen, or any rectangular area. It's usually expressed as a ratio of two numbers, such as 16:9 or 4:3. Aspect ratio determines the shape and visual proportions of content, making it an important concept in design and media production.
aspectRatioCalculator.calculationFormula: Calculating aspect ratio is simple: divide both width and height by their greatest common divisor to get the simplest ratio. For example, a 1920√ó1080 resolution has a GCD of 120, so the aspect ratio is 16:9. When you need to maintain the same ratio while resizing, use the formula: New Height = (Original Height √∑ Original Width) √ó New Width.
aspectRatioCalculator.widescreen169Description: 16:9 is the most common modern aspect ratio, widely used in HD TVs, computer monitors, YouTube videos, and most modern devices. This ratio provides a wide field of view, perfect for watching movies and gaming.
aspectRatioCalculator.traditional43Description: 4:3 is the traditional TV and computer monitor ratio, widely used in early CRT monitors and old TVs. While less common now, it's still important in certain professional applications and legacy content.
aspectRatioCalculator.square11Description: 1:1 square ratio is very popular on social media, especially Instagram posts. This ratio displays well on mobile devices and is commonly used for avatars, icons, and certain artwork.
aspectRatioCalculator.ultrawide219Description: 21:9 ultrawide ratio is mainly used in film production and high-end monitors. This ratio provides a wider field of view, particularly suitable for movie watching, gaming, and multitasking.
aspectRatioCalculator.responsiveDesignDescription: In responsive web design, understanding different device aspect ratios is crucial. Designers need to ensure content displays correctly across various screen ratios, from narrow mobile screens to wide desktop displays.
aspectRatioCalculator.videoProductionDescription: In video production, choosing the correct aspect ratio determines the visual effect and compatibility of the final work. Different platforms have different recommended ratios: YouTube recommends 16:9, Instagram Stories uses 9:16, while movies typically use 21:9.
aspectRatioCalculator.imageEditingDescription: In image editing, maintaining the correct aspect ratio prevents image distortion. When resizing images for different purposes, understanding how to calculate proportional dimensions is very important.
aspectRatioCalculator.howToUse: How to Use the Aspect Ratio Calculator?
aspectRatioCalculator.step1: Enter the original width and height values
aspectRatioCalculator.step2: Enter a new width or height in the new dimensions area
aspectRatioCalculator.step3: The other dimension will be automatically calculated to maintain the same ratio
aspectRatioCalculator.step4: View the visual preview to understand the ratio effect
aspectRatioCalculator.exampleCalculation: For example: If the original dimensions are 1920√ó1080 (16:9), when you enter a new width of 3840, the calculator will automatically calculate the new height as 2160, maintaining the same 16:9 ratio.
aspectRatioCalculator.webDesign: Web Design: Create responsive layouts for different devices
aspectRatioCalculator.videoEditing: Video Editing: Resize videos to fit different platforms
aspectRatioCalculator.imageResize: Image Resizing: Scale images proportionally to avoid distortion
aspectRatioCalculator.printDesign: Print Design: Ensure designs maintain proportions at different sizes
aspectRatioCalculator.socialMedia: Social Media: Create content sized for various platforms
aspectRatioCalculator.photography32Description: 3:2 is a commonly used ratio in traditional photography and is also the standard ratio for 35mm film. This ratio is also common in digital cameras and tablets, providing good compositional balance.
aspectRatioCalculator.classic54Description: 5:4 ratio is commonly used in early computer monitors and some professional displays. This ratio is between 4:3 and 16:10, and has certain applications in document processing and graphic design.

whatIsRatio.question: What is aspect ratio?
whatIsRatio.answer: Aspect ratio is the proportional relationship between width and height, usually expressed as a ratio of two numbers (like 16:9). It determines the shape of a rectangular area and is a fundamental concept in design and media production.

whyMaintainRatio.question: Why maintain aspect ratio?
whyMaintainRatio.answer: Maintaining aspect ratio prevents image or content distortion. When you resize without preserving the original ratio, images may be stretched or compressed, resulting in poor visual quality.

commonRatios.question: What are the most common aspect ratios?
commonRatios.answer: The most common include 16:9 (modern displays and video), 4:3 (traditional displays), 1:1 (social media squares), 21:9 (ultrawide), and 3:2 (commonly used in photography).

calculateManually.question: How to calculate aspect ratio manually?
calculateManually.answer: Divide both width and height by their greatest common divisor. For example, 1920√∑120=16, 1080√∑120=9, so the ratio is 16:9. Or use the formula: New Height = (Original Height √∑ Original Width) √ó New Width.

projectionCalculator.title: Projector Distance Calculator
projectionCalculator.intro: Calculate the optimal projector distance and screen size for your room. Enter your projector's throw ratio and desired screen size to get precise installation measurements.
projectionCalculator.pageTitle: Projector Distance Calculator - Calculate Screen Size & Throw Distance | Screen Size Checker
projectionCalculator.pageDescription: Calculate the optimal projector distance and screen size for your room. Enter throw ratio and distance to get precise measurements for home theater or conference room setup.
projectionCalculator.pageIntro: Calculate the optimal projector distance and screen size for your room.
projectionCalculator.throwRatioHelp: Throw ratio = Distance / Screen Width. Check your projector specs.
projectionCalculator.distanceHelp: Distance from projector lens to screen
projectionCalculator.screenSizeHelp: Desired screen diagonal size in inches
projectionCalculator.aspectRatioHelp: Most projectors use 16:9 for home theater
projectionCalculator.throwRatioExplain: Throw ratio is the relationship between the projector's distance from the screen and the width of the projected image. It's calculated as: Throw Ratio = Distance √∑ Screen Width.
projectionCalculator.calculateFormula: The basic formula is: Distance = Throw Ratio √ó Screen Width. For a 16:9 aspect ratio screen, the width is approximately 87% of the diagonal size.
projectionCalculator.viewingExplain: For the best viewing experience, the optimal viewing distance is typically 1.5 to 2.5 times the screen diagonal.
projectionCalculator.tip1: Check your projector's specific throw ratio in the manual or specifications
projectionCalculator.tip2: Account for lens shift and zoom range when planning placement
projectionCalculator.tip3: Ensure the projector is level and perpendicular to the screen
projectionCalculator.tip4: Consider ceiling mount for permanent installation
projectionCalculator.tip5: Leave space for ventilation and cable management
projectionCalculator.tip6: Check for ambient light control options in your room
projectionCalculator.lumensIntro: Screen size affects how bright your projector needs to be. Larger screens spread the light over more area, requiring more lumens.
projectionCalculator.faq1q: How do I find my projector's throw ratio?
projectionCalculator.faq1a: Check your projector's specifications sheet or manual. It's usually listed as a single number (e.g., 1.5) or a range (e.g., 1.2-1.9) for projectors with zoom lenses.
projectionCalculator.faq2q: What size screen should I get for my room?
projectionCalculator.faq2a: The ideal screen size depends on your viewing distance and room size. A general rule is that the screen diagonal should be about 1/3 to 1/2 of your viewing distance.
projectionCalculator.faq3q: Can I use a short throw projector for a large screen?
projectionCalculator.faq3a: Yes, but there are trade-offs. Short throw projectors can create large images from short distances, but may have more geometric distortion at larger sizes.
projectionCalculator.faq4q: What's the difference between throw ratio and throw distance?
projectionCalculator.faq4a: Throw distance is the actual physical distance between the projector and screen. Throw ratio is a multiplier that relates this distance to screen width.
projectionCalculator.faq5q: How does aspect ratio affect screen size calculations?
projectionCalculator.faq5a: Different aspect ratios have different width-to-height proportions. A 16:9 screen is wider relative to its height than a 4:3 screen.

lcdTester.title: LCD Screen Tester
lcdTester.intro: Test your monitor for dead pixels, color accuracy, and display quality. Run comprehensive screen tests in fullscreen mode.
lcdTester.pageTitle: LCD Screen Tester - Test for Dead Pixels & Display Quality | Screen Size Checker
lcdTester.pageDescription: Free online LCD screen tester. Check your monitor for dead pixels, color accuracy, backlight bleeding, and display quality issues.
lcdTester.pageIntro: Test your monitor for dead pixels, color accuracy, and display quality.
lcdTester.deadPixelDesc: Display solid colors to detect dead or stuck pixels on your screen.
lcdTester.gradientDesc: Check color uniformity and banding issues with smooth gradients.
lcdTester.grayScaleDesc: Test grayscale rendering and contrast levels.
lcdTester.patternDesc: Detect pixel alignment and sharpness issues.
lcdTester.colorDesc: Evaluate color accuracy and display calibration.
lcdTester.motionDesc: Check for ghosting and response time issues.
lcdTester.textDesc: Verify text rendering and font clarity.
lcdTester.autoTestHint: Press ESC or click to exit. Press Space or Arrow keys to navigate.
lcdTester.instruction1: Click any test button to start fullscreen test
lcdTester.instruction2: Press ESC or click anywhere to exit test
lcdTester.instruction3: Use Arrow keys or Space to switch between colors/tests
lcdTester.instruction4: Clean your screen before testing for accurate results
lcdTester.instruction5: Test in a dimly lit room for best visibility
lcdTester.deadPixelsInfo: Small dots that don't change color. Visible as black spots on bright colors or bright spots on black.
lcdTester.stuckPixelsInfo: Pixels that stay one color. Usually visible as bright colored dots (red, green, or blue) that don't change.
lcdTester.colorBandingInfo: Visible steps or bands in gradients instead of smooth transitions. Indicates limited color depth.
lcdTester.backlightInfo: Light leaking around edges or corners, especially visible on black screens in dark rooms.
lcdTester.faq1a: Dead pixels are usually permanent. However, stuck pixels can sometimes be fixed by running pixel-cycling software or gently massaging the affected area with a soft cloth.
lcdTester.faq2q: How many dead pixels are acceptable?
lcdTester.faq2a: Most manufacturers allow 1-5 dead pixels depending on screen class. Premium 'zero dead pixel' warranties are available from some brands.
lcdTester.faq3a: Fullscreen mode ensures the test covers every pixel and removes UI elements that could hide defects. It also provides accurate color display without browser interference.
lcdTester.faq4a: Backlight bleed is caused by uneven light distribution from the LED backlight, often due to manufacturing tolerances or pressure on the panel frame.
